sentences.text: So hello everyone I am Vick Shant. So today we will be learning about UPS.

improvement.reason: Typo in 'UPS' and it's an acronym that should be fully introduced.
improvement.suggestion: So hello everyone, I am Vick Shant. Today we will be learning about OOP, which stands for Object-Oriented Programming.

sentences.text: UPS object oriented programming, we will take a real simple example of a coffee machine and we will see. So think of the coffee machine as a class, it is like a blueprint.

improvement.suggestion: In Object-Oriented Programming, we'll use a simple example of a coffee machine. Think of the coffee machine as a class, which is like a blueprint.

sentences.text: It defines the functions of a coffee machine like making a coffee, making a cappuccino, alate etc. Now when you buy a real coffee machine it is like an object, right it is buy it and place on a table like an object. Now let us come to the UPS part of it.

improvement.suggestion: This blueprint defines the functions of a coffee machine, like making a coffee, a cappuccino, or a latte. When you buy a real coffee machine, it's like an object—you buy it and place it on a table. Now let's dive into the core concepts of OOP.

sentences.text: So the OAPS has four different pillars. The first one is encapsulation.

improvement.suggestion: OOP has four different pillars, or core principles. The first one is encapsulation.

sentences.text: Now what is encapsulation? It's the capsule, right? What is the capsule? It has some medicine inside, and it's hidden by the outer capsule.

improvement.reason: The analogy is good, but the direct programming definition of encapsulation is missing.
improvement.suggestion: What is encapsulation? Think of a medicine capsule: it holds medicine inside, hidden by the outer shell. In programming, encapsulation is about bundling data and the methods that operate on that data into a single unit, and hiding the internal details.

sentences.text: Now in terms of the coffee machine, a coffee machine has some internal wiring, it has a heating element, it has a coffee grinder.
It's all hidden under the outer casing. Now this is encapsulation like bundling of data and hiding under a casing.

improvement.reason: The explanation is good but could be more explicit about 'data and methods' in a programming context.
improvement.suggestion: All the internal wiring, heating elements, and coffee grinders are hidden under the outer casing. This is encapsulation: bundling related data and methods together and hiding their internal workings from the outside.

sentences.text: Now moving on to the next one, it is abstraction. Now it may seem like a big term, but really isn't.
Now suppose I want to express it. Now how do you say to the machine, like I just press a button off, I press one and it gives me an express.

improvement.reason: Unclear phrasing ('express it', 'press a button off, I press one') and 'express' should be 'espresso'.
improvement.suggestion: Now, suppose I want to make an espresso. How do I interact with the machine? I simply press a button, and it gives me an espresso.

sentences.text: I don't care about the steps to make an express, right, that is handled by the machine.

improvement.suggestion: I don't care about the complex internal steps to make an espresso; that process is handled by the machine internally.

sentences.text: So it is, the machine is abstracting the function to make an express and simply giving me a button.

improvement.suggestion: So, the machine is abstracting the complex function of making an espresso and simply providing me with a button to achieve the desired outcome.

sentences.text: That is abstraction. Moving on to the next one, it's inheritance.
Now inheritance is really simple. It's like you inherit your father's property, right?
Now in terms of the coffee machine, like suppose you have a smaller coffee machine, and then your budget increases and you buy a premium one.
Now suppose the smaller one only makes espresso and heats up water.
And the premium one, it makes tapucino, it makes elate and also makes, it definitely makes an espresso and heats up water, right?

improvement.suggestion: And the premium one makes cappuccino and latte, and it definitely also makes an espresso and heats up water, right?

sentences.text: So it is inheriting the properties of the base one and also addigates own properties.

improvement.reason: Typo in 'addigates' and 'properties' could be more specific to programming.
improvement.suggestion: So, the premium machine is inheriting the properties and behaviors of the base model while also adding its own unique features.

sentences.text: Now think in terms of cars, you have a base version and then you have a higher end model.
Now obviously the higher end model has all the features of the base one plus some extra features, right?
Now moving on to the last one, which is fallen more fissom. Now it seems like a complex term, but it's really simple.

improvement.suggestion: Now moving on to the last one, which is polymorphism. It may seem like a complex term, but it's really simple.

sentences.text: What it simply means is many forms or multiple forms.
Now suppose I have two coffee machines, one of brand X and one of brand Y.
Now I know I have a same button, brew on both of them. Now when I press the brew button on the brand X, it makes an espresso.
When I press the same button on brand Y, it makes a filter coffee.
Now the same function, the same button, performs multiple function, it appears in multiple forms.

improvement.suggestion: So, the same function, triggered by the same button, performs multiple functions or appears in multiple forms depending on the object.

sentences.text: That is polymorphism. That's right time guys. I have my vaccine everything well.

improvement.reason: The latter part of the sentence is off-topic and unprofessional for a technical lecture.
improvement.suggestion: That is polymorphism. Thank you for your time, everyone.

sentences.text: Thank you so much.
